title: Modular Large Language Model Agents for Multi-Task Computational Materials Science
abstract: The integration of large language models (LLMs) with domain-specific computational tools offers a promising pathway to streamline and enhance materials science workflows. This paper presents MatSciAgent, a multi-agent framework capable of performing key tasks such as materials data retrieval, continuum simulation, crystal structure generation, and molecular dynamics simulation. At the core of the framework is the master agent, which interprets the user’s natural language query, identifies the task type, and delegates it to a corresponding task-specific agent equipped with appropriate computational tools. Leveraging databases such as the Materials Project and MatWeb, the framework retrieves and summarizes materials data with grounded, factual responses—addressing a key limitation of vanilla LLMs. In cases where the target material is not found in existing databases, a generative task-specific agent can propose plausible crystal structures. For simulation tasks, dedicated agents extract relevant parameters from the user query to conduct continuum simulations (e.g., Cellular Automata and Monte Carlo Annealing) and atomistic simulations (e.g., Molecular Dynamics) using both established software and custom code. The modular design of these agents and their associated tools enables seamless extensibility, allowing the framework to evolve as new capabilities are integrated.

Modular Large Language Model Agents for
Multi-Task Computational Materials Science
Akshat Chaudhari,† Janghoon Ock,‡ and Amir Barati Farimani∗,¶,§,∥,‡

Abstract
The integration of large language models (LLMs) with domain-specific computa-
tional tools offers a promising pathway to streamline and enhance materials science
workflows. This paper presents MatSciAgent, a multi-agent framework capable of
performing key tasks such as materials data retrieval, continuum simulation, crystal
structure generation, and molecular dynamics simulation. At the core of the frame-
work is the master agent, which interprets the user’s natural language query, identifies
the task type, and delegates it to a corresponding task-specific agent equipped with
1
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
appropriate computational tools. Leveraging databases such as the Materials Project
and MatWeb, the framework retrieves and summarizes materials data with grounded,
factual responses—addressing a key limitation of vanilla LLMs. In cases where the
target material is not found in existing databases, a generative task-specific agent can
propose plausible crystal structures. For simulation tasks, dedicated agents extract rel-
evant parameters from the user query to conduct continuum simulations (e.g., Cellular
Automata and Monte Carlo Annealing) and atomistic simulations (e.g., Molecular Dy-
namics) using both established software and custom code. The modular design of these
agents and their associated tools enables seamless extensibility, allowing the framework
to evolve as new capabilities are integrated.
Introduction
Materials science and engineering are central to technological progress, enabling the dis-
covery, design, and optimization of materials tailored to specific performance requirements.
Emerging industries such as aerospace, energy, and biotechnology increasingly demand ma-
terials with precisely engineered mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties. Designing
such materials is a complex and iterative process that requires deep domain expertise and
advanced computational techniques. As a result, researchers are increasingly leveraging com-
putational tools to predict and optimize material behavior, accelerating the development of
materials with targeted functionalities. 1,2
This shift has driven the creation of large-scale materials databases—including the Ma-
terials Project, 3 MatWeb,4 OQMD,5 and ICSD6—which serve as critical resources for data-
driven materials discovery. Predictive models built on these databases are increasingly used
to guide materials design decisions. 7 In particular, generative models—machine learning al-
gorithms that learn patterns from data to generate new, plausible candidates—are being
adopted to propose novel material compositions or structures, further accelerating discov-
ery.8–10 However, despite these advancements, integrating various simulation tools and data
2
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
sources into a unified framework remains a significant challenge. This lack of integration
limits the seamless use of computational resources and hinders the pace of innovation in
materials design. 11
Recent advances in artificial intelligence—especially the emergence of large language
models (LLMs)—have reshaped how researchers engage with complex data and derive sci-
entific insights. Built on transformer architectures, 12 these models excel at understanding
and generating natural language through self-attention mechanisms, enabling scalable pro-
cessing of language-based information. LLMs, such as OpenAI’s GPT models, 13,14 Meta’s
LLaMA,15 and Anthropic’s Claude, 16 have demonstrated exceptional capabilities in inter-
preting user queries, synthesizing information from diverse sources, and producing actionable
insights. In the context of materials science, LLMs support tasks such as information ex-
traction from large databases, literature mining, and hypothesis generation. Their ability to
process unstructured natural language queries allows researchers to intuitively explore com-
plex datasets, reducing manual effort and accelerating scientific workflows.17–19 Additionally,
transformer-based language models have proven effective as encoders for property prediction
tasks across a range of scientific domains, including metal-organic frameworks,20 polymers,21
catalysis,18,19 proteins,22–25 inorganic crystals, 26,27 and additive manufacturing. 28
LLMs are now being integrated into agentic frameworks that extend their utility from pas-
sive query interpretation to active scientific problem-solving.29,30 These LLM agents leverage
the model’s language understanding, pre-trained knowledge, and emerging planning abilities
to autonomously perform complex tasks. For instance, Boiko et al. introduced Coscientist,
an LLM-driven agent that automates experimental design and execution, substantially re-
ducing manual effort. 31 Similarly, ChemCrow combines LLMs with chemistry-specific tools
to support synthesis planning and materials discovery. 32 Such agentic systems are being
applied across diverse scientific domains, including not only materials science and chemistry
but also fields like 3D printing and engineering design. 33,34
While LLMs demonstrate strong capabilities in natural language processing and gen-
3
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
eral reasoning, their application in specialized scientific domains such as materials science
presents several challenges. One of the most significant concerns is hallucination, where
LLMs produce information that appears plausible but is factually incorrect. 35–37 Such out-
puts can mislead researchers, disrupt workflows, and lead to wasted resources. This issue is
particularly problematic when interpreting technical datasets, as LLMs are typically trained
on general-purpose corpora that lack sufficient coverage of domain-specific materials science
knowledge.38,39
Furthermore, LLMs alone are inherently limited in delivering rigorous scientific predic-
tions for complex physical phenomena, as such tasks require high-precision, physics-based
simulations and validated numerical methods. To overcome this limitation, LLMs must be
integrated with domain-specific scientific software, enabling them to function as user proxies
that automate the setup and execution of simulation workflows. Several hybrid frameworks
have emerged to support this vision—LLaMP, 40 HoneyComb,41 and AtomAgents42—which
couple LLMs with scientific tools and databases. LLaMP and HoneyComb primarily function
as retrieval agents, leveraging data sources like the Materials Project, arXiv, and Wikipedia.
AtomAgents is a more specialized system designed to support alloy development through
integration with multimodal perception, reasoning capability, and materials design tools. As
research continues, there is a growing need for a more generalizable and modular framework
that can accommodate a broader range of materials systems and simulation tasks, while
remaining flexible enough to incorporate newly developed computational tools.
We propose MatSciAgent, a multi-agent framework that integrates an LLM with spe-
cialized computational tools to perform tasks based on natural language user queries. As
illustrated in Figure 1, the system supports four task types: materials retrieval, continuum
simulation, crystal structure generation, and molecular dynamics simulation. Each task is
handled by a dedicated task-specific agent, coordinated by a central master agent. The
master agent interprets the user’s input, determines the type of task, and delegates the
query to the appropriate task-specific agent. The assigned agent then selects the relevant
4
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
Multi AgentMaterial Scientist(MatSciAgent)
Figure 1. Illustration of the multi-agent architecture, showcasing how each agent leverages
input from the user, integrates with domain-specific tools, and utilizes the reasoning capa-
bilities of the LLM to process tasks and generate outputs. OpenAI’s GPT-3.5-turbo serves
as the core LLM in this framework.
computational tools needed to complete the task. All decisions, from task classification to
tool selection, are guided by the reasoning capabilities of the LLM. This framework demon-
strates how LLMs can enhance computational materials science by automating workflows,
improving accessibility to simulation tools, and accelerating research processes.
Agentic Framework
Multi-Agent System
The workflow consists of two key steps: First, when a user submits a query, a master agent
classifies the task type and routes the query to the appropriate task-specific agent. Then,
5
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
the task-specific agent selects and deploys the most suitable computational tools to solve the
problem, delivering results back to the user. Built on OpenAI’s GPT-3.5-turbo, it employs
customized prompts for domain-specific reasoning and tool integration. The modular ar-
chitecture supports diverse tasks, including data extraction, continuum simulations, crystal
structure generation, and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, ensuring easy expansion
with new agents, tools, or workflows.
Each individual agent is powered by an LLM, equipped with task-specific tools, and oper-
ates with shared memory supported by a scratchpad, as shown in Figure 2. A key strength is
its agentic design, where each agent operates independently and is equipped with specialized
tools and prompts. Shared memory maintains context, enabling iterative problem-solving.
The LLM serves as the reasoning layer, dynamically interpreting queries and orchestrating
tool use. By combining LLM-driven reasoning with the precision of computation tools, the
system can handle complex queries, perform precise calculations, and generate analyzable
insights.
Prompt engineering and structured tool integration enhance adaptability. Carefully de-
signed prompts define each agent’s operations, while integrated tools handle specialized
computations like MD simulations or property data extraction. The LLM remains focused
on reasoning and decision-making while delegating computationally intensive operations to
these tools. A centralized execution framework manages input parsing, tool invocation, and
response formatting, ensuring seamless interaction between the LLM’s reasoning and the
tools’ deterministic computations.
Materials Extraction
LLMs, while powerful, are typically trained on general-purpose natural language datasets and
lack access to the specialized, structured data required for materials science applications.43,44
Because they rely on static, pre-trained knowledge, they cannot dynamically query authori-
tative databases, often resulting in outdated or incomplete information. Furthermore, their
6
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
Figure 2. Components of an LLM agent. User input is structured using a prompt template
that includes a system message, dialogue history, user query, and a scratchpad for interme-
diate results. The LLM processes the prompt, and an output parser determines whether
a tool invocation is needed. If so, the tool execution engine runs the specified tool and
updates the scratchpad with the results. This updated scratchpad is reintegrated into the
prompt template for iterative processing. The final result is produced once no further tool
invocations are required.
probabilistic nature can lead to overgeneralization or misinterpretation of complex scientific
queries.45
To overcome these limitations, we introduce a materials extraction agent that integrates
the Materials Project API and custom web-scraping for MatWeb, enabling real-time access
to validated, domain-specific data. Upon receiving a user query, the agent retrieves relevant
material properties—such as thermal, dielectric, and surface characteristics—by invoking
the appropriate database call, either via API or web scraping. It then synthesizes a natural
language response based on the retrieved data. This method ensures that responses are
grounded in current, authoritative sources, allowing for more accurate contextualization of
materials, verification of properties under specific conditions, and delivery of reliable, data-
driven insights critical for real-world applications. Importantly, by relying on scientifically
7
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
validated sources, the system also enhances the reproducibility of output prompt generation.
The agent retrieves data from structured databases, including the Materials Project3 and
MatWeb.4 The Materials Project offers access to over 150,000 materials with properties such
as elasticity, phonon spectra, and thermodynamic stability—essential for predictive model-
ing. MatWeb complements this with experimentally validated material data, enabling direct
comparisons between computational predictions and empirical behavior. Further implemen-
tation details are provided in the Methods section.
Continuum Simulation
The continuum simulation agent executes advanced materials science simulations, integrating
two key modeling techniques: Cellular Automata (CA) 46,47 for phase transformations and
Monte Carlo Annealing (MCA) 48,49 for microstructural evolution during annealing. Users
provide simulation conditions in natural language, which the agent translates into actionable
parameters before executing the simulation.
The CA tool models phase transformations such as solidification and recrystallization
by iteratively updating a 2D grid based on local neighborhood conditions. It accounts for
attachment probabilities and tracks transformed regions over time, offering insights into
grain growth and nucleation in both single-phase and multiphase systems.
MCA tool, using the Potts model, 50 simulates the evolution of the grain structure under
annealing conditions. Operating near zero temperature, it employs three biasing strategies:
unbiased selection, neighboring flavor selection, and interface bias selection to model inter-
face and bulk site behaviors. This method enables a detailed analysis of grain boundary
dynamics and energy minimization during thermal processing, offering predictive insights
into microstructural stability.
Understanding phase transformations and microstructural evolution is essential for tai-
loring material properties in manufacturing and processing. By integrating CA and MCA
within an LLM framework, it enhances traditional modeling tools with natural language in-
8
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
teraction, parameter customization, and visualization. It delivers actionable insights through
simulation results.
Crystal Structure Generation
Atomic structure is fundamental to understanding inorganic crystal materials and performing
computational simulations. When structural data is available in existing datasets, it can be
directly retrieved. However, if such data is missing, alternative methods are needed to
generate the desired atomic structures.
The crystal generator agent addresses this by generating crystal structures based on
elemental compositions or alloy systems using CrystaLLM, a transformer-based language
model specifically designed to produce CIFs (Crystallographic Information Files) of inor-
ganic crystals. 8 Upon receiving a user query, the agent extracts relevant information and
runs CrystaLLM to generate plausible inorganic crystal structures. It can produce multiple
candidate structures for a given composition, enabling material exploration.
Unlike general-purpose LLMs, CrystaLLM is tailored to recognize complex crystallo-
graphic patterns, enabling the generation of physically realistic structures. As part of a
multi-agent system, the crystal generator agent streamlines materials workflows by providing
immediate input for downstream tasks such as thermodynamic stability analysis, property
prediction, and MD simulations.
Molecular Dynamics
Atomic-scale simulations are essential for understanding fundamental material behaviors,
such as thermal conductivity, mechanical strength, and phase transitions. 51,52 The MD sim-
ulation agent is designed to automate and streamline atomic-scale simulations. It interprets
user input queries, sets up the appropriate simulation parameters, and executes the MD sim-
ulation accordingly. Specifically, the agent initializes atomic structures, defines interatomic
potentials, and runs simulations using tools primarily based on the Atomic Simulation En-
9
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
vironment (ASE) package.53
It supports the construction of atomic structures with various crystal symmetries and
accommodates a range of interatomic potentials, including the Embedded Atom Method
(EAM),54 Lennard-Jones (LJ),55 and Effective Medium Theory (EMT).56 These enable sim-
ulations of metals, alloys, and simple molecular systems. The agent can also perform simu-
lations under different thermodynamic ensembles—NVE (constant energy), NVT (constant
temperature), and NPT (constant pressure)—allowing users to explore material behavior
under controlled conditions. Further details are provided in the Methods section. By trans-
lating natural language input into simulation-ready parameters, the agent simplifies the MD
simulation workflow.
Integrating the MD simulation tools with an LLM agent significantly enhances its capabil-
ities. Users can interactively configure simulations, analyze results, and visualize atomic tra-
jectories using natural language queries. Unlike traditional standalone MD tools, this agent
automates the entire workflow—from structure initialization to result interpretation—providing
actionable outputs such as energy plots and trajectory data with minimal manual effort.
Case Study
Materials Extraction
Case 1. Synthesis of Perovskite Oxides for Solar Cells
The task begins with the user query: “Provide synthesis details for perovskite oxides used in
solar cells.” A comparison between the materials extraction agent and the vanilla GPT-3.5-
turbo is summarized in Figure 3. The materials extraction agent first identifies key terms
from the query—namely “perovskite” and “solar cells” —using its reasoning capabilities. It
then invokes the materialsproject API to retrieve relevant data from the database. This
approach enables the agent to deliver more specific and detailed information than the vanilla
10

GPT-3.5-turbo. For example, it identifies specific compositions such as La0.8Sr0.2CoxFe1−xO3
and provides corresponding precursor details. It also outlines precise synthesis protocols,
including temperature conditions and duration. In contrast, GPT-3.5-turbo returns only
generic information and fails to offer detailed synthesis procedures.

Case 2. Bonding Information for TiO 2
The user input query in this task specifies a particular material and requested properties,
such as: “Retrieve bond length and coordination information for TiO 2. List your results.”
The agent first identifies the task as a material/property extraction query and summarizes
the retrieved information, as shown in Figure 4. In this case, the target material is TiO 2,
and the properties of interest are bond lengths and coordination environments. Because
TiO2 exists in multiple structural forms—each associated with a unique material ID—the
agent begins by retrieving all relevant material IDs. It then uses a set of tools to extract the
bonding properties for each structure.
Because the agent has access to the Materials Project database, it generates response
prompts based on real, up-to-date data. In contrast, the vanilla GPT-3.5-turbo relies solely
on its pre-trained knowledge, without access to external sources. Although only one summary
is shown below for illustration, the agent produces a separate summary for each retrieved
structure, ensuring thorough coverage of all known structural variants of the material.
Case 3: Materials within a Specific Heat Capacity Range
The user query specifies a target property range—specific heat capacities between 0.1 and
2.0 J/g·◦C—along with additional guidelines, such as ensuring material diversity and priori-
tizing experimentally verified data (Figure5a). The agent begins by identifying the property
of interest and its specified range, then queries the MatWeb database to retrieve relevant
materials and generates a structured response (Figure 5b). For comparison, Figure 5c shows
the output from the vanilla GPT-3.5-turbo for the same input.
The agent identifies example materials within the specified heat capacity range and sup-
plements this with additional thermal, mechanical, and compositional properties. For in-
stance, silver (Ag) is retrieved with a specific heat capacity of 0.234 J/g ·◦C, along with a
density of 10.491 g/cc, thermal conductivity of 419 W/m ·K, and melting point of 961.93 ◦C.

Case 2: Ti-Al Intermetallic Alloy Solidification with Interface-Controlled Growth
In this case study, the continuum simulation agent is applied to model interface-controlled
growth in an alloy system. The agent interprets the user’s natural language query, extracts
the relevant simulation parameters, and executes a CA simulation to generate frame-by-
frame images of microstructural evolution during solidification, as shown in Figure 7. The
simulation results reveal smooth, isotropic growth behavior, characterized by uniformly ex-
panding grains without the formation of dendritic arms—consistent with the high attachment
probability conditions. Controlled nucleation, set at 50 nuclei per unit area, leads to evenly
distributed grains across the domain, resulting in a homogeneous microstructure. The high
attachment probability also enhances solid–liquid interface kinetics, promoting the formation
of uniformly sized grains with minimal solute segregation.

Case 3: Polycrystalline Grain Growth Using Monte Carlo Annealing
This task involves performing an MCA simulation to model polycrystalline grain growth.
Unlike the previous two case studies, the agent applies the MCA simulation tool based on
the description provided in the user query. The simulation, conducted on a 50 ×50 lattice
grid, demonstrates classic grain coarsening behavior—larger grains grow at the expense of
smaller ones. The lattice initially contains randomly oriented grains, but over the course of
100 Monte Carlo steps, the system evolves to minimize interfacial energy. Grain boundaries
shift, especially at interfaces where different grains meet, driving the reduction of total grain
boundary energy. This results in a coarser microstructure, characterized by fewer, larger
grains—consistent with the typical grain growth behavior observed during the annealing of
polycrystalline materials.

Conclusion
The integration of LLMs with simulation tools demonstrates their growing utility in compu-
tational materials science. This paper showcases their effectiveness in structure retrieval and
generation, as well as in running continuum and MD simulations. The case studies highlight
20
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
the flexibility of LLMs in automating workflows that incorporate both custom code and es-
tablished software. The agent consistently extracts relevant parameters and search keywords
from natural language input with high accuracy.
A key strength of the framework is its modular design, which allows it to expand as
new tools are added. Broadening data sources beyond the Materials Project and MatWeb
would further enhance its applicability. Simulation capabilities could be improved through
advanced workflows, multiscale modeling, and ML-guided optimization. Moreover, enabling
the agent to dynamically write or adapt code would increase its flexibility, making it better
suited for novel or specialized tasks.
Methods
Materials Database
The Materials Project is an open-access database designed to support computational ma-
terials science research. 3 It contains over 170,000 material entries, all generated using first-
principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The database offers a comprehensive
set of material properties, including crystal structures, formation energies, band structures,
density of states, elastic tensors, bulk and shear moduli, Poisson’s ratio, dielectric con-
stants, magnetic properties, phonon dispersion (for selected materials), and surface energies.
The dataset is continuously updated, and users can access it programmatically via a well-
documented API, commonly through tools like pymatgen.
MatWeb is an online database that focuses on experimentally measured or manufacturer-
provided material properties. 4 It features over 180,000 material datasheets, covering a wide
variety of materials such as metals, alloys, polymers, ceramics, composites, and glasses.
MatWeb provides detailed information on mechanical properties (e.g., tensile strength, yield
strength, hardness), thermal properties (e.g., thermal conductivity, expansion coefficients),
electrical properties, chemical compositions, and physical constants like density and specific
21
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
heat.
Cellular Automata
In this work, the Cellular Automata model is used to simulate phase transformations such as
solidification or recrystallization within a two-dimensional, grid-based system. Each cell in
the grid represents a point in space and can exist either in the liquid phase, denoted by 0, or
in one of several solid phases, represented by positive integers. The transformation process
is driven by local interactions between neighboring cells and governed by an attachment
probability, allowing the model to effectively capture the evolution of microstructures during
phase changes.
The model is defined by several key parameters. The width specifies the size of the
square simulation grid, and the simulation is restricted to the interior cells to avoid boundary
effects. The attach prob parameter controls the likelihood that a liquid cell will transform
into a solid phase based on its neighbors. When this value is set to 1, the transformation
is deterministic, while lower values introduce randomness, resulting in probabilistic growth
behavior. The num solid states parameter determines how many distinct solid phases can
exist in the system. When set to 1, the model simulates basic solidification with a single
growing phase; when greater than 1, it enables more complex recrystallization scenarios,
where multiple phases grow and compete for space.
Nucleation is introduced through the place nuclei(num nuclei) function, which ran-
domly places a specified number of initial solid cells throughout the grid. Each nucleus
is assigned a random solid phase. The system then evolves over a series of discrete time
steps using the evolve(Nsteps) function, which updates each cell based on the states of its
neighbors.
The output of the simulation includes visual snapshots of the evolving microstructure
at each time step, as well as a plot showing the fraction of the transformed area over time.
This transformation curve can be compared to analytical predictions based on the Johnson-
22
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
Mehl-Avrami-Kolmogorov (JMAK) theory, 57 providing a means of validating the model’s
behavior.
Monte Carlo Annealing
Monte Carlo Annealing is used to simulate grain growth or spin ordering in a two-dimensional
Potts model at very low temperatures ( T ≈ 0), where the system dynamics are governed
primarily by energy minimization. 49 This corresponds to zero-temperature Metropolis dy-
namics, in which spin flips are only accepted if they lower or maintain the system’s energy.
Each site on the 2D lattice can exist in one of Q possible states, and the system evolves by
locally minimizing interfacial energy between different states.
The model is characterized by several key parameters. The variableQ defines the number
of possible states or “flavors” per lattice site, which can represent, for example, distinct grain
orientations in a polycrystalline material. The parameter L sets the size of the square lattice,
resulting in a total of L×L sites. The simulation proceeds for a given number of Monte Carlo
steps, with each step consisting of L2 spin-flip attempts. The biasing strategy determines
how both the site and the trial state are selected during simulation. Strategies include
selecting a random new state from all Q options, choosing from neighboring states at any
site, or restricting to neighboring states only at interfacial sites (i.e., those bordering unlike
neighbors).
This simulation produces several outputs that help analyze the system’s behavior. The
energy history tracks how the total energy of the lattice evolves over time, typically decreasing
as the system anneals. The acceptance history records the number of accepted spin flips per
Monte Carlo step, providing insight into how active or “frozen” the system becomes during
the simulation. The configuration history stores snapshots of the lattice at each step, allowing
visualization of the evolving microstructure and phase ordering. If plotting is enabled, the
simulation also generates visualizations of the energy curve, acceptance rate, and both initial
and final configurations. Additionally, it can save all configuration snapshots as images in a
23
https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
results directory for further analysis.
CrystaLLM
CrystaLLM is a domain-specific LLM designed to generate crystallographic structures in CIF
format from basic compositional input. Built on the GPT-2 architecture and adapted using
the nanoGPT implementation, 58,59 CrystaLLM has been purposefully trained for applica-
tions in inorganic materials science. Rather than relying on general-purpose vocabularies, it
uses a custom byte-level tokenizer with a vocabulary of 371 tokens tailored to the syntactic
patterns of CIF files.
The training dataset for CrystaLLM was assembled from multiple high-quality mate-
rials science databases, including the Materials Project, 3 the Open Quantum Materials
Database,5 and the NOMAD. 60 These sources provide a diverse range of inorganic crys-
tal structures, enabling the model to learn detailed patterns related to atomic arrangements,
symmetry operations, and lattice parameters across a wide variety of crystal systems.
We employ the small variant of CrystaLLM in our study, which consists of 8 transformer
layers, each with 8 attention heads and a context window of 1,024 tokens. The model has
an embedding dimension of 512 and was trained from scratch for 5,000 iterations.
Molecular Dynamics Simulation
MD simulations were conducted using the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE) to inves-
tigate the structural evolution of atomic systems under various thermodynamic conditions.
The agentic framework enables the execution of MD simulations in NVE (constant energy),
NVT (constant Number, Volume, Temperature), and NPT (constant Number, Pressure,
Temperature) ensembles. Thermodynamic control was achieved using the Berendsen ther-
mostat for temperature regulation and the Berendsen barostat for pressure regulation in
NPT simulations.
Key simulation parameters include the time step for numerical integration, target tem-

https://doi.org/10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-zkn81-v2 ORCID: https://orcid.org/0009-0000-0370-4212 Content not peer-reviewed by ChemRxiv. License: CC BY-NC 4.0
perature, and the total number of MD steps. For ensemble control, the thermostat and
barostat time constants were specified, along with external pressure and barostat coupling
strength for NPT conditions. Additionally, a logging interval was defined to record system
properties and trajectories at regular time steps. Simulation outputs consist of atomic tra-
jectories saved in .traj format, log files detailing the evolution of energy, temperature, and
stress, and corresponding visualizations of energy and temperature profiles over time.
